body: This is a very useful PR and required to pave the way for some larger scale changes so we should try to get this in.
Thanks @jaehc, we'll try to get to reviewing this soon. We are really backlogged on PRs right now.
üëç

Some context:

This is meant to be an adapter from an Appenderator (#2220) into the Plumber interface. Right now Appenderators are only used by the KafkaIndexTask. @javasoze has been working on a custom Appenderator as an extension and wanted to use it with realtime nodes too, which this would help with.

The motivation for the custom Appenderator is that @javasoze is wanting to create a new segment type based on Lucene indexes rather than the traditional Druid columnar format with smooshes and all that.

The hope is that with some changes in Druid we could support more than one kind of segment format, where "base" queries (like topN, timeseries, groupBy) work on all formats, but maybe additional extension queries only work on specific formats, or maybe certain features (like certain filters) would be implemented in more optimal ways on certain formats.

The first step towards experimenting with that is making it possible to customize segment creation via implementing a custom Appenderator, which this PR helps with by making that interface usable in realtime nodes. If that works out then we'd also want to make it usable in batch ingestion and in realtime tasks.

@navis some more comments. BTW, a good reference aggregator to look at is the HyperUniqueAggregator. I think this aggregator looks very similar to HLL and can be built without requiring changes to interfaces.

Fixed an issue where if the supervisor crashed after signalling a task to begin publishing but before creating the next task, the succeeding supervisor would create the new task with the same starting offsets as the publishing task. It will now create the new task starting from where the publishing task ended. Also added a test for this.
@drcrallen I am not sure how much it fixes, but there were some obvious differences, especially around how tabs are treated etc.
@drcrallen this is really needed in 0.9.1?

üëç
@noddi is this a bug, as the fig shows, index task's duration is always 0, - Druid version: 0.9.0 - Problem:
@fjy it broke one of our unit tests in spark batch indexing, so yes
@drcrallen @b-slim what is the progress here?

Since 74f4572bd49a04b4ca381fcd7b8f360c8ef52480 I don't think it's possible to have a semantic equals/hashCode impl for DataSchema that avoids creating the parser (which seems like a good thing to avoid‚Ä¶ it'd be weird if equals/hashCode triggered that). Two semantically equivalent parsers could be made from two different maps. (even before druid-io/druid-api#75 this could happen because e.g. `dimensionExclusions: []` and `dimensionExclusions: null` do the same thing)

Since it's not possible to get these methods right, I think we should remove them (verifying we don't need them in production code) and have the tests be a little more verbose.
@b-slim can we finish this up?

@fjy @javasoze can we get some broader context on this? It would be worthwhile to submit a proposal to the mailing list for discussion: it sounds like there has been a lot of private discussion already that would be worthwhile sharing with the community.

Looking through production usages I don't see anything that would rely on equals/hashCode being semantic, so I think they're safe to remove. (it doesn't seem to be used as a key in a map, or in some other object's equals method, or called directly so far as I can see)
@fjy it is in the pipeline...
@gianm we still need a way to test DataSchema serde
@drcrallen please check out https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2925

Test the fields for equality individually? There's only 4, the test wouldn't be _THAT_ verbose. That's probably more honest than implementing an equals method that doesn't (and really, can't) work properly.

@xvrl, definitely, although we have not yet figured out the details of a proposal so there is nothing concrete to share yet. Hoping to have something there soon-ish. The goal though is to make it possible to store a Druid dataSource using some engine other than Druid's traditional storage engine (like Lucene).

Probably in addition to this PR, a sketch of a fuller proposal is,
- using Appenderator for batch ingestion too (there's already an `Appenderators.offline` builder method that should work for this)
- somehow abstract over IndexIO so `SegmentLoader` can use different loading strategies for getting `Segment` objects, other than `IndexIO.loadIndex` to allow historicals to load segement with alternative storage engines
- something in `Segment` that lets query engines get different interfaces other than `QueryableIndex` and `StorageAdapter`, maybe `T as(Class<T> clazz)` where `as(StorageAdapter.class)` would do the same thing as `asStorageAdapter()` but could also be used for interfaces that only exist in extensions. this would allow queries to use features that are only present in alternative storage engines. if those engines also implemented StorageAdapter, then all existing queries would work on them too.

I think these changes could be done in a pretty non-invasive way and then open up some cool possibilities for storage engine extensions.

Hopefully this PR can be reviewed before a fuller proposal is ready.
@gianm maybe a better solution is to remove the parser field from the data schema, since the parser just defines how to read the data, but has nothing to do with the actual schema in Druid

It unfortunately does have to do with the schema, because the parser defines both the data format and the dimensions for the schema. IMO that is a bit weird though, it should probably only define the format.

Unrelated to that, it's also weird that inside the parser, the ParseSpec sometimes defines the data format (if you're using the string input row parser) but sometimes doesn't (if you're using any other input row parser).

Anyway, I do think both of those are weird and we could do a better API, but that is how it works right now, and changing either would be backwards incompatible‚Ä¶
is there any benefit of getting this merged before we flesh out the proposal?
merged, I'm not sure (@javasoze?), but looked at ‚Äì¬†that always helps :)
@drcrallen let me know when this is ready.

Thanks @gianm for providing the context.

@xvrl I guess I had hoped the AppenderatorPlumber would be a general purpose extension point where people can do interesting things with Druid.

I used @gianm's branch and was able to plug-in full-text support through Lucene via this extension point and thought it would be interesting to explore further.

I am not sure if this PR should be treated as a simple extension point or part of a larger roadmap. Personally I am a fan of small incremental changes that make sense.

So I would like to get an opinion from the community to see if this extension point makes sense in general without making it a dependency of a larger discussion/roadmap.

Hope this makes sense.

Thanks!
@b-slim the non-kafka stuff should be ready
@sirpkt I'm going to move this PR to a MMX branch. Since most of the reviewers are in my timezone I can have faster modifications while they are awake.
Moved to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2926

What do you all think about this approach for making equals() work?

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2927
@jon-wei how would you feel about making the equals checking a static method in `ParseSpec`?
Hm, discussed this in person with @gianm just now, he brought up the point that this doesn't properly compare the parser, in that it only checks the type and not any other properties...
@drcrallen do you mean a static method that compares a parseSpec represented as a Map?
@jon-wei yes, but in `ParseSpec` instead of in `DataSchema`
It came up in the dev-sync, but the origination of the separation comes from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1695
@drcrallen moved the Map->ParseSpec serde to a static method on ParseSpec
Also updated this to compare the "parser" map by making a copy and nulling out the "parseSpec" field.

This is still an imperfect solution, in that any "parser" subfields with "different but equivalent" semantics would still fail the equality check, in the same way that the update to DimensionsSpec caused the map-based ParseSpec comparison to fail when comparing equivalent String/Map representations of the dimensions.
@drcrallen OK

I see this issue too with a Druid GIT pull from today

But the error only happens when I run as user 'root' this is a JVM issue where FILE.canWrite behave different if you are user 'root' - why because the 'root' user always can write on some UNIX system - more on this at the bottom. BTW this seems to solve #2694 also.

My test system is probably in the "under-powered" test case one hard drive 4GB RAM

Okay back to this is a JVM issue given the follwoing test program lets run it first as a non root user and then as a root user:

```
import java.io.File;

public class TestIssue {
    public static void main(String[] args){
        File f = new File("wibblefish");
        f.deleteOnExit();
        if (f.mkdirs())
            if (f.setWritable(false,false)) {
                if (f.canWrite()) {
                    System.out.println("Test failed");
                } else {
                    System.out.println("Test passed (setWritable() succeeded)");
                }
            } else {
                System.out.println("Test Passed (setWritable() failed)");
            }
    }
}
```

Hi @acslk thanks for the contribution! would you mind filling out the [CLA](http://druid.io/community/cla.html)?

Also, do you have performance or benchmarking numbers to back this up?

fixed in #2867

@drcrallen @pjain1 hm, seems like your computers are too fast, slow them down :P

The supervisors table uses the current time as part of the primary key, and when the test creates two entries in quick succession they are getting the same timestamp and thus conflicting. We could put in some logic to handle this, but I don't think this scenario would ever come up outside of a test (the rules table also uses the current time in the same way and I don't think we've had any issues with this), so it might make more sense to just throw some sleeps into the test to ensure we get different timestamps unless someone feels strongly against this.
@dclim Is it possible to use a latch instead of sleeps? Sleeps can be funky in travis and cause more transient errors, although with a large enough sleep it is usually pretty good

@dclim relying on ms time has bitten us in the past. If you can add a UUID or hostname or something in there it should help eliminate the potential for two machines in the cluster to do something in the same ms (or what they think is the same ms)
@drcrallen fair enough, I don't really see any significant issues with adding a uuid to the primary key so I'll do that

This seems like a ton of hoops to jump through for really little benefit. I'm not gonna block it if people want to get it in, but I really don't see a need for DataSchema to have equals¬†or hashCode methods. The API choice of embedding the parser in the schema, while also trying to avoid deserialization of the parser, just makes all this really awkward.

One other point in favor of _not_ having them is that DataSchemas logically include InputRowParsers, and those don't override equals or hashCode either (nor should they IMO). 

If we are gonna go this way, we should at least fix hashCode such that it is consistent with equals. With the current implementation it is possible for two instances to equal each other but have different hashCodes.
Thanks for the contrib, can we ad some UTs please.
@gianm is there a reasonable way to shake out where removing hashCode and equals would break things?
